trans-unit.source: Serves as the base class for controls that reside in <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase"></xref> zones, and that provide catalogs of available Web server controls (especially <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> controls) that users can add to a Web page.
The CatalogPart class is a base class for special controls that reside in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase> zones.
These derived CatalogPart controls provide catalogs of Web server controls that end users can add to a Web page.
Use CatalogPart controls in a Web application when you want to provide end users with the flexibility to change the functionality of a Web page by adding or removing server controls.

A catalog is simply a list of one or more available Web server controls (including <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, ASP.NET server controls, and custom or user controls) that users can add to a Web page.

A catalog has a number of common characteristics, including instruction text for end users; text to describe each server control; helper controls to select the server controls and add them to the page; a common header, footer, and border; and a number of style attributes.
There are three types of CatalogPart controls provided with the Web Parts control set, as described in the following table.
Each type of CatalogPart control contains server controls that are added to a page from a different source.
> [!IMPORTANT] > Controls that inherit from the CatalogPart class can reside only in zones derived from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase> class.

|Control|Description| |-------------|-----------------| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PageCatalogPart>|Contains controls that have been closed on a page, and that can be reopened (added back to the page) by users.

The controls in this type of catalog are controls that were already added to the page from another source, and were then closed by a user.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.DeclarativeCatalogPart>|Contains server controls declared within a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.DeclarativeCatalogPart> control, which is itself contained in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase> zone in the markup of a Web page.| |<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ImportCatalogPart>|Provides the user interface (UI) for a user to upload a control's definition file (an XML file defined by a schema, that contains state information) to a catalog, so that the control can be added to a Web page.

The controls themselves do not appear in this type of catalog; the catalog is just a mechanism for accessing the definition files for external controls so they can be added to a page.| The CatalogPart class inherits from the base <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part> class, so that it has the common behavior of other part controls in the Web Parts control set.
In addition, it adds some members that are useful for the catalog functionality.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart.DisplayTitle%2A> property gets the actual string that is currently being displayed as the title of the control.

The value of this property can be the same as the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.Title%2A> property or, if no value has been assigned to that property, a default value supplied by the .NET Framework.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart.WebPartManager%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart.Zone%2A> properties both provide convenient access to the two essential objects that control the life cycle of a CatalogPart control: the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase> zone that contains the CatalogPart control, respectively.
The CatalogPart class also contains several methods.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart.GetAvailableWebPartDescriptions%2A> method is declared as an abstract method that must be implemented by inheritors.
Its intended purpose is to return a collection of descriptions of the controls in the catalog.
A related method, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart.GetWebPart%2A>, is also declared as abstract and must be implemented by inheritors.
This method is intended to return an instance of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control based on a description that is passed to the method as a parameter.
Initializes the class for use by an inherited class instance.
This constructor can only be called by an inherited class.
Gets a string that contains the actual current title of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart"></xref> control.
The DisplayTitle property returns either the current value of the base <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.Title%2A> property or, if the control has no title, a calculated value.
The DisplayTitle property is designed to be a read-only, calculated property to get the actual current value of the displayed title at run time.
Therefore, you should not attempt to use this property to set a title for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart> control.
To set a title, use the base <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.Title%2A> property.
A string that represents the complete, visible title of the control.
The default value is an empty string ("").
Returns a collection of descriptions of the available <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> controls in a catalog.
The GetAvailableWebPartDescriptions method returns description information for each control in a catalog.

A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescription> object is a lightweight object that contains essential information about a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control, including its ID, an object reference to the control, and the values of several important properties that are inherited from the base <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part> class, such as <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.Title%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.Description%2A>.
The GetAvailableWebPartDescriptions method improves performance.
When a catalog is created, it needs some information about each control it contains, including a title, a description, an icon (if one exists), and an ID.

Rather than having to create an instance of each control to get this information, a caller can use the GetAvailableWebPartDescriptions method, which returns only the description information about each control.

A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescriptionCollection"></xref> that contains a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescription"></xref> for each control in a catalog.
Retrieves the current state of a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart"></xref> control's parent zone.
The GetDesignModeState method returns information about the state of the zone that contains a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart> control.
The state information is returned in the form of a dictionary.

An <xref:System.Collections.IDictionary> that contains the current state of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase"></xref> zone that contains a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart"></xref> control.

Retrieves from a catalog the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control that is referenced by the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescription"></xref> object passed to the method.
The GetWebPart method returns a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control from a catalog.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescription> object that is passed to the method matches a specific <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control and enables that control to be returned by the method.

If a catalog contains a server control that does not derive from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class, such as an ASP.NET server control, a custom server control, or a user control, a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart> control must wrap the server control with a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control, and return the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> control from this method.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartDescription"></xref> that contains a reference to a specific <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref>.
A that is referenced by the object in the description parameter.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.

The OnPreRender method calls the base <xref:System.Web.UI.Control.OnPreRender%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, and ensures that an instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase> class has been created.
An <xref:System.EventArgs> that contains the event data.

The <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase"></xref> that contains the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart"></xref> control is <xref uid="langword_csharp_null" name="null" href=""></xref>.
Sets design-time data for a control.
An <xref:System.Collections.IDictionary> containing the design-time data for the control.
Gets a reference to the current instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager"></xref> class.

The WebPartManager property provides a way for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart> control to access the current <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> object on the page.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager"></xref> for the current Web page.
Gets a reference to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase"></xref> zone that contains a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart"></xref> control.
The Zone property enables a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogPart> control to get a reference to its zone.
Although the property is read-only, the underlying properties of the zone itself can be changed programmatically.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.CatalogZoneBase"></xref> that corresponds to the zone that contains the control.
